trans-unit.source: Retrieves the current color of the specified display element

target.mrk: Retrieves the current color of the specified display element

trans-unit.source: Parameters

seg-source.mrk: Parameters

target.mrk: Parameters

trans-unit.source: The display element whose color is to be retrieved. Can be one of the following:

seg-source.mrk: The display element whose color is to be retrieved.
Can be one of the following:

target.mrk: The display element whose color is to be retrieved.
Can be one of the following:

trans-unit.source: $COLOR_3DDKSHADOW - Dark shadow for three-dimensional display elements.

trans-unit.source: Return Value

seg-source.mrk: Return Value

target.mrk: Return Value

trans-unit.source: Returns the red, green, blue (RGB) color value of the given element

seg-source.mrk: Returns the red, green, blue (RGB) color value of the given element

target.mrk: Returns the red, green, blue (RGB) color value of the given element

trans-unit.source: Remarks

seg-source.mrk: Remarks

target.mrk: Remarks

trans-unit.source: Above constants require #include <WindowsConstants.au3>

seg-source.mrk: Above constants require #include <WindowsConstants.au3>

target.mrk: Above constants require #include <WindowsConstants.au3>

trans-unit.source: If the $iIndex parameter is out of range, the return value is zero. Because zero is also a valid RGB value, you cannot use GetSysColor to determine whether a system color is supported by the current platform. Instead, use the GetSysColorBrush function, which returns NULL if the color is not supported.

seg-source.mrk: If the $iIndex parameter is out of range, the return value is zero.
Because zero is also a valid RGB value, you cannot use GetSysColor to determine whether a system color is supported by the current platform.
Instead, use the GetSysColorBrush function, which returns NULL if the color is not supported.

target.mrk: If the $iIndex parameter is out of range, the return value is zero.
Because zero is also a valid RGB value, you cannot use GetSysColor to determine whether a system color is supported by the current platform.
Instead, use the GetSysColorBrush function, which returns NULL if the color is not supported.
